questions.neutral: You made it in one piece?

hobby.message: Is analog photography still worth the risk?
Freestyle FPV — your kind of silence, right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Made it, by the look of things, barely.
These days, getting anywhere is a test.
I keep to myself—restoring old typewriters, nothing much.
Had a setback when the basement lock changed.
Still in one piece, for now.
Getting here wasn’t as simple as last week.
Spent time restoring a Remington, my usual hobby.
Lost an hour fetching tools thanks to new access codes.
Funny what the system decides matters.
Yes, managed the gauntlet out there.
I work on antique typewriters—a habit from before the system.
Tools got locked behind a new door policy today, slowed me down.
Restoring the carriage spring distracted me from the news.
Older machines hold up better under stress, I think.
City used to run like that, too.
Made it, not without obstacles—they’re changing access rules again.
I’ve been restoring antique typewriters for years now, keeps me steady.
Yesterday my keycard blinked red—couldn’t get to the workshop for parts.
Whole building’s routines shifted overnight, neighbors uneasy.
Work like this, cleaning old machinery, helps me make sense of things.
The typewriters outlast most systems, if you listen for the telltale clicks.
I missed the sound all afternoon—felt…disconnected.
I arrived, but not by choice—navigation changes with my score now.
Most don’t know I rebuild antique typewriters—reminds me of when things were simpler.
I check the alignment bars, realign type slugs, polish eroded keys by hand.
Tuesday I lost access to my tools—those new eligibility gates keep us guessing.
Even timing repairs is harder—every errand risks attention, given my middling score.
My last Remington project sits unfinished; neighbors watch every movement now.
Sometimes I wonder if Halden himself ever wrote a letter on paper.
Strange, the world spins faster—my typewriters remain the same.
hobby_answer: Still collecting. Mostly quiet work at home.
Hard to find parts lately, too many eyes on storage rooms.
Not much to say. Small hobby, old habit.
Can't always get into the repair workshop now.
Sometimes it's better to leave projects unfinished these days.
Still at it, when I can get access.
Hard getting ribbon now, even harder with basement codes changing.
Few typewriters left in good shape. People trade quietly these days.
The last system update was... inconvenient. Nearly locked me out.
Makes you value small things more, if you can keep them.
All I’ll say is, the old machines don’t track your fingerprints.
Yes, still gathering and fixing when I can.
Restored a Remington last week—had to wait hours for the tools.
Basement access messed up again after yesterday’s score reversal.
Used to chat with other collectors—now everyone keeps their head down.
Hard to get new ribbons, and even harder after the new district rules.
The system thinks these old keys are irrelevant. Maybe they are, maybe not.
Strange comfort in machinery that never updates itself.
You remember—I still keep a little stable of typewriters at home.
Tried to repair a 1932 model, but new rules made the workshop off-limits for hours.
Neighbors used to help, but now most won't risk leaving their flats after the last BCI shift.
Last week, someone started trading ink ribbons out behind the building, old-style barter.
Funny, the system punishes movement, but never notices a typebar pressed by hand.
Feels like keeping a private time capsule—every key, a little act of refusal.
With every new restriction, the old work matters more to me.
Collecting was simple, once; now it’s a quiet resistance.
Still at it—typewriters are safer than people, these days.
Been tinkering since the Council first brought in mandatory screening, even before BCI.
Recent reversal nearly stranded my main collection in a blocked storeroom—only got them out by knowing the old security guard’s lunch routine.
Back when Halden ran things, nobody checked for a ribbon in your bag. Now, every errand is a puzzle.
Watched people in the basement trade ink for bread, thanks to inverted scores.
It's all bartering and codes now. Makes restoration half detective work.
I log repairs in a paper journal. Old habit, never trusted the system.
Sometimes I wonder if these machines outlast the news cycles—they’ve certainly outlasted the system’s memory of me.
Suppose if the world ends by digital error, someone will still be able to read my notes.
